item.name: Get Request - Part 7 Auth Passed Valid Search Params - Update User Agent Copy

request.description:
Inspect the REQUEST headers with the headers you are sending with Postman (and not the response header you get from the server).

What value does the header User-Agent have?  ---ANSWER PostmanRuntime/7.22.0

Tip: If you do not find the header, make sure to revisit the lecture Troubleshooting inside this section.

Postman request has 4 parts

1. Request method - post, get, put, etc..
2. URL where request should go
3. Headers
4. Body
5. 

query param ?foo=bar , foo is the key, bar is the value

Taking a lengthy URL and substituting values for ease to troubelshoot later

Logic:
https://enw0ub0vb8s9p.x.pipedream.net/users/5/contracts/2 --users with id 5 and contracts from that user selecting contract type 2

The above will work without any problem but in postman we can do the following

rpath variables ---replace 5 with :userid and 2 with :contractid and now we can pass values, global or local set from previous requests {{gvalue}}

Submitting the request with the Path Variables the ending result will be GET - /users/5/contracts/2/

Headers are comprised of Key, Value pairs.

There are already predefiend headers

Headers are related to what type of contents we are sending.

Imagine you have registration form that you want to test, with form-data you can do that. Doesnt have to do it with Restful API, Postman just supports it...

For a Post we are retreiving items from the server, so the Path Variable within the URL will not be seen on the server side

The key difference between form-data nad x-ww-form-urlencoded is it will URL encode the value you submit within the request. 

Similar to Get RestBin - URL Decoding request.

On the server you will see RAW form of the key value be middleNameURLEncoded=encoded%20encoded%0A%0A. Space at end is always appended

Postman autoamtically adds header 'content-type'

For Headers you can BulkEdit multiple Headers instead of doing line by line.

For Headers you can se Presets by managing your own set if you dont want to type everytime. By doing this you can simply add them from Presets drop down, select the headers you want added and it will automatically popluate in the Headers list.

The raw option can use various types of text, for ease we use the JSON selection option

Just like previous requests we have seen the select of the type of body you are using will add a header value for you automatically.

When raw is selected the header key, pair value added is content-type application/json

You can beautify your requesy by selecting ctrl+B....

Binary is deisgned for information that you want to deisgn to API or Server buy you CANT directly enter using Postman.

For raw you could to this with JSON but it would require alot, for example sending an image would require

1. opening the image 
2. get its contents
3. PUt here in raw part
4. Paste it
5. Submit the request

Complicated so send image and send to server using binary and on the server you will see the exact contents of that message
You can also send a file for form-data if you would like to

Analyze responses

What is happening with request, what is server responding with

HTTP has three parts
1. Status Code --success (200) or not (400), 2 is okay, 4 is not, or server response (500) not your fault
2. Body -- how response is returned (pretty is nice, raw is somtimes hard to see, preivew is how we)
3. Headers  -- in a HTTP request or response is the additional information that is transferred to the user or the server. In postman, the headers can be seen in the Headers tab

Save Responses
1. Used for API documentation

Cookies are technically just a header and are specific to the site being visited. 

From within Headers  in response Set-Cookie instructs the browser to save this cookies name, value, expiration time and domain which it is valid for
   -when sending cookies the Cookie header is being used
   -when receiving cookies the Set-Cookie header is being used 
      - the Set-Cookie will most likley be seen the first time in the response headers. Request bin noticed that we already have a Cookie so no reason to send Set-Cookie again
      
Use Cookie Manager to add and manage cookies

Postman, similar to browser will keep all existing cookies

In this exmaple the example.con we performed a get and the address i not valid. 

The Postman Console will give any information we need.

We are using https://www.udemy.com/course/postman-the-complete-guide/learn/lecture/12305516#bookmarks

Want to use boards endpoint with updating a board in trello, it is a PUT

https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/trello/rest/#api-boards-id-put

Says we shold use endpoint - https://api.trello.com/1/boards/{id}  --full path must be provided

PUT /1/boards/{id}

Update an existing board by id  -- trello board URL - https://trello.com/b/5fEoNUfU/myboardupdate -- ID of board 5fEoNUfU

Request
PATH PARAMETERS   =--- PATH PARAMETERS ARE ID which is 
value - id 
boolean must include = REQUIRED 
object type = string

Pattern: ^[0-9a-fA-F]{32}$
QUERY PARAMETERS
value = name 
object type = string

The new name for the board. 1 to 16384 characters long.


Finalized URL Example
https://api.trello.com/1/boards/1234?name=New Board Name

1. Require URL per API Documentation - https://api.trello.com/1/boards/
2. To udpate id we add /{id} as stated in documentation
   -Path parameters are 
     -everything with '/' OR 1234 in our example as defined in API documentation AFTER required URL
        OR
     -everything before '?' Queray Parameters
3. Add Query Parameters after path parameters
  -Query Paramteres are everyhing with ? and after are query parameters


Updated URL Example in Postman
1, Path Parameters can be updated to make it easier just like query params 
2. Postman Substite URL Value is ":value" so for this example its :id which can now be subscrituted in URL to give
https://api.trello.com/1/boards/id:?name=New Board Name - as soon as you add :id you will be Path Parameters show

We are using https://www.udemy.com/course/postman-the-complete-guide/learn/lecture/12305516#bookmarks

https://api.trello.com/1/boards/{id}
--substitute '1' and {id}
--Note that path paramteres cant be turned on and off like query paramters as if you remove the path paramters then you change the PATH which will not be the same which would not allow you sit the endpoint / address that you want to

To obtain ID of board in trello its the numberic portion of this URL

item.name: Variable Scopes - set up different URL's using env's in Postman

request.description:
Up to this point have uses key and value pairs from global variables stored (i.e.. trelloKey and trelloToken, etc...)

Always room for improvement

This request does nothing

Goal
1. To not repeat yourself
2. Write varibale once or to update it automatically
3. Dont want to same information all over the place


Variable Types
Will only handle Environment and Global
  -there is a hierachy to this.
  -if same variable defined in both global and environmental the enviornmental variable will win because the scope is narrower

item.name: Global Variables - Create Board - Store ID

request.description:
To use variables in request define them and then use {{VariableName}} so they can be used within Request builder
 -Request builder is anything that has to do with Params, Authorization, Headers and Body
 
Set and Get Global Variables
     1. accces it -- pm.globals.get("variable_key")
     2. set it -- pm.globals.set("variable_key","variable_value")
 
 When defined should be added to Global Environment List (eye icon top right)
 
 
 Unset and Clear Global Variables
     1. remove global variable done need anymore - pm.globals.unset("variable_key")
         -can be removed after request / response or when no longer need
     2. clear all global variables - pm.globals.clear();
     
Assignment for this request
1. Create request with new board name
--We will create a board using trello API, documentation states to use the following URL 
--API Documentation - https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/trello/rest/#api-boards-post
--API URL - https://api.trello.com/1/boards/?name={name}
2. Verify board name 
3. Verify board is private
4. Save ID of Board as Global Variable --once stored we can use it any other request or collection

item.name: Global Variables - Create ToDoList - Pass Board ID

request.description:
Pass Global Variable when Creating List within Board

API Documentation - https://developer.atlassian.com/cloud/trello/rest/#api-boards-id-lists-post URL to use - https://api.trello.com/1/boards/{id}/lists?name={name} 

For {id} value we are using GlobalValue BoardID from "Global VAriables - Create Board - Store ID" and using it within the Request builder and veriying in test scripts

Then we clear global variable pm.globals.unset("variable_value")


RULE - when we are dont with data delete or clear it so we dont have to manage it later

Environment Variables have narrower scope 
Use Case 
 -have two different environmental variables, one that can be used in production and one that can be used in staging
 
Setup
 -select eye icon from top right hand side, select environment variables add name and add values. 

Test
 - BEFORe environment setup hover over token or vey value and notice scopt says Global
 - NEXT update environment, select new evnrionment created in Setup and repeat hovering over values, observe they say Environment now


To Sum Up
 -when no environment variable selected Postman will check for Global Variables with that key/value pair, 
 -if Environment selected Postnam will search for Environment variables with that key/value pair
 
 Advantages - 
  -Environment Variables - can have multiple environments with same variables (different values) and sames requets, just need to point to environment
  -Global Variables - can only have one variable with one values, no multiple

Scripting Environment Variables

set environment variable - pm.environment.set("variable_key", variable_value)
get environment variable - pm.environment.get("myVariable")
unset and clear value for environment variable - pm.environment.unset("myVariable")
clear all environment variables - pm.environment.clear()

Introduced in Postman 6.2,

If you view Variables you see two values 

Session Variables - 
  Initival Values - variables shared within collection when exported (only used for exporting)
  Current Values - never shared with collection

The values which are confidential like token and key you could mark as 'YOURKEY' and 'YOURTOKEN' leaving other path and query params within the request builder the same. This way when a collection is exported and shared your secret key and token is not shared and the other user who will use it can pass their own information. Makes secure and safe

Note - initial and current do not have to be the same, they will so by default though. Current Value is the value Postman will use

Same logic as Global, Environment, Session variables

To go to go to Collection Name->Edit->Variable (these are collection variables)

All variables depend on where we want to save them and allow access to them

item.name: PreRequest Scripts - Creating Const Pre Request Script
PreRequest Scripts - Creating Function Pre Request Script
PreRequest Scripts - Set and Get Dynamic Board Name
Variable Scopes - Understanding Variable Scopes + Types

request.description:
When it makes sense to use variable type

https://medium.com/@vdespa/demystifying-postman-variables-how-and-when-to-use-different-variable-scopes-66ad8dc11200

Global, Collection, Envrionment,  Data and Local Variables
 -if two variables are named the same the one closes to request in relation to hierarchy will be chose, (ie... local closest and global furthest)
 
 
 Gloabl Variables - ideal for quick response and protyping (setting up test intitially and seeing if it works)
     -avoid using as much as possible
     -only use as last result
     -clear after being used
      -USE scoped getter to see which variables are being used in the space pm.variables.get()
      
 Environental Variables - ideal when working with multiple servers (staging vs prod)
     -good alternative to global variables
     -allows storing of environment information easily (URL's, authentification information)
     -updating and passing data to other requestis (Section 4 assignment 3 for example)
     -clear after being used
     -avoid naming same as global varibles (mixing)
     -USE scoped getter to see which variables are being used in the space pm.variables.get()
     
 Collection Varaibles - ideal for storing constants, enums (values cant be updated)
    -cant be updated with scripts
    -good use for credentials which do not change, URL's, etc....
    -eliminates duplicate variables
    -avoid and only use if necessary, environmental variables better
    -USE scoped getter to see which variables are being used in the space pm.variables.get()
    
 Data Variables - ideal for working with multiple data sets
    -exist only during iteration of run
    -can only be set from CSV or JSON File

item.name: Variable Scopes - Setup different URL's using env's in Postman

request.description:
For setup added below environments

https://readthedocs.org/projects/postman-quick-reference-guide/downloads/pdf/latest/

local - example-local.com
QA - example-qa.com
Production - example-production.com

Once an environment is set it is avaivable to all collections and all requets associated within.
  -if using continuous integration then dont forget to export each environment
    -user a updates, user b needs newest collection, so user a exports and then user b uploads newest collection
    
If need to access environmental variables in scripts just use PM API (pm.environment.get('url'))

Store Environment Variables for Information - If you need to know which environment you are currently in create another variable within the environment which stores this (ie.. environment/local for example.

Can write conditional tests to execute / create somethinf around IF statement for example 

console.log(pm.environment.get('url'));
console.log(pm.environment.get('environment'));

if (pm.environment.get('environment') == 'production'){
    pm.environment.set("Pass", "ifTest");
}



YOU CAN USE as many environment variables to 'Store Environment Variables for Information' if lets say things within your environment constantly change, like parts within the URL for example
   -add to conditional if statement as enedd

Strategy for Debugging Tests and Request

-Use Postman Console
 -console.log you can check any variable, output of function, etc and see what your test is outputting.
 -different levels of output depends on what you want
 
 Example:
  -response body gives you three levels, 
    -response
      -prefs
      -etccc.
      
 console.log(response);  --gives you all levels
 console.log(response.prefs);  --gives you just prefs level
 console.log(response.prefs.hideVotes);  --gives you value of hideVotes value
  
 if there is a value which does not exist then a null will be returned in response, you may use this for a conditional statement as in some tests some x values should not be seen so if value null return true, etc..

Assignment 4 - Step 4

item.name: GitHub - get repo for authenticated user

request.description:
URL - https://developer.github.com/v3/repos/#list-repositories-for-the-authenticated-user
All URLs returned in JSON and must begin with https://api.github.com

Information Given - GET /user/repos

If run https://api.github.com/user/repos a generic message will be retuned indicating github is a protected endpoint in which we must pass valid credentials / other way to know who we are

Solution (can use others, just depends on what api endpoint options are vailable for user to use) 
 -Authorization Tab->Basic Auth (for type)->enter github user credentials

2FA - Additional layer af security usually taken in the form of a one time password (otp)

Two ways to do with github
1. SMS Message
2. TOTP (time based one time password) - based (user needs to scan QR Code like Google Auhtenticator) then during log in process code will be seen within application

To setup
1. Log into github
2. From your profile select Settings
3. Select Account Security
4. Select Enable Two Factor Authentification
5. For ease we will use SMS Method, [Set up using SMS]
6. List of Recovery Codes returned (from this copy somewhere safe)
7. Setup using your phone number

Verify two factor response has been enabled

Note - if you logout and login you will have to redo step 7

Attempting to run request which previously worked (will reue GitHub - get report for authenticated user as example) will now fail because of two factor authentification, observe 401 is returned

API Documentation (as retunred in error response) - https://developer.github.com/v3/auth#working-with-two-factor-authentication

Important Part
Using the OAuth Authorizations API with two-factor authentication
When you make calls to the OAuth Authorizations API, Basic Authentication requires that you use a one-time password (OTP) and your username and password instead of tokens. When you attempt to authenticate with the OAuth Authorizations API, the server will respond with a 401 Unauthorized and one of these headers to let you know that you need a two-factor authentication code:

X-GitHub-OTP: required; SMS or X-GitHub-OTP: required; app.

This header tells you how your account receives its two-factor authentication codes. Depending how you set up your account, you will either receive your OTP codes via SMS or you will use an application like Google Authenticator or 1Password. For more information, see "Configuring two-factor authentication." Pass the OTP in the header:

This is a continuation form Postman - Setup for 2FA

1. When using Basic Auth with 2FA we need get a new OAuth Authorization code to be able to run requests

API Documentation - https://developer.github.com/v3/oauth_authorizations/#create-a-new-authorization

URL - POST /authorizations


IMPORTANT - you will get an error stating you must specify 2FA and that is OKAY, this just generates the 2FA needed for your other request

Short introduction to NodeJs and NPM
The next lectures will introduce some new tools and software and is rather advanced. I am in the process of recording more detailed videos on this section but until they are ready, where are some general information you should be aware of.

Overview of the NodeJs and NPM ecosystem
NodeJs is a JavaScript runtime environment that can execute JavaScript without opening a browser. Newman runs inside the NodeJs runtime environment, so this is why NodeJs needs to be installed (locally on your computer or on the server running Jenkins or any other CI server). More details on nodejs.org.

NPM is the Node Package Manager. This is like a repository of projects and has knowledge of what requirements each project has. For example, you want to install Newman, but it depends on other libraries which themselves depend on other libraries. To figure out all the dependencies each project needs, you just need to have NPM installed and NPM will do this work for you. 

In the next video, I have defined Newman as a dependency for my project. This means that the project I have created, cannot run without Newman. When NPM checks the packages.json file, it will figure out what it needs to install, in order for my project to run.



Installation
Windows - basic installation steps can be found here: http://nodesource.com/blog/installing-nodejs-tutorial-windows/

General tip: always restart Windows after installing new software.

macOS

- with Homebrew (my preferred way) - https://www.dyclassroom.com/howto-mac/how-to-install-nodejs-and-npm-on-mac-using-homebrew

- without - https://coolestguidesontheplanet.com/installing-node-js-on-macos/

Linux 

- with Ubuntu

- for other distros, please just search for "install node and npm on ..."

Cross-platform

If you are familiar with Docker, there is a Docker image that has Newman and all the dependencies already installed. Just let me know so that I can point you in the right direction.

Newman 

Installation
- in order to install you must have NodeJS and NPM already installed
- node --version = command to run in terminal to check if you have nodejs installed
- npm --version = command to run in terminal to check if you have npm installed
- npm -install -g newman = command to run in terminal to install newman
- newman --version = command to run in terminal to check if newman installed sucessfully


Overview + Benefits
- Allows you to use a CLI to run the collection directly from the terminal.
- Think of how it can be used for continuous integration and automation, postman always needs interaction.
- This tool fills the need of understanding Postman and Jenkings, MIDDLEWARE

Troubleshooting Node.js / npm / Newman Problems (for Windows)
Windows - Troubleshooting Node.js / npm / Newman Problems
=======================================================
1. Node.js cannot be called from the command prompt
Once you have successfully installed Node and restarted your computer, when you open a command prompt terminal and type in node -v, you get an error and not a version like v6.9.5

Possible solution

In Windows, you need to set node.js folder path into system variables.

1) open Control Panel -> System and Security -> System -> Advanced System Settings -> Environment Variables

2) in "System variables" find variable PATH and add node.js folder path as value. Usually it is C:\Program Files\nodejs;. If variable doesn't exists, create it. 

3) Restart your computer.

2. Newman cannot be called from the command prompt
Once you have installed newman and restarted your computer, when you open a command prompt terminal and type in newman --version, you get an error and not a version like v4.1.0

Possible solution

In Windows, you need to set the folder where node.js is storing global dependencies into system variables.

1) open Control Panel -> System and Security -> System -> Advanced System Settings -> Environment Variables

2) in "System variables" find variable PATH and add the folder path as value. Usually it is something like: C:\Users\YOURUSERNAME\AppData\Roaming\npm

Inside the folder you should see a file called newman.

3) Restart your computer.

Going to specific version of newman (backwords compatible, etc... say update breaks a lot of things)

Installating newman reporter

item.name: Using Newman w/ Postman API - Obtaining Environments

request.description:
Continuation of Preview step - Using Newman w/ Postman API - Acccess ALL Collections & Individual Collections using PM
 
Use below options to obtain what information you need
- 1 Fetch a list of your collections from: https://api.getpostman.com/collections?apikey=$apiKey
- 2 Get the collection link via it's uid: https://api.getpostman.com/collections/$uid?apikey=$apiKey 
- 3 Obtain the environment URI (uniform resource identifier) from: https://api.getpostman.com/environments?apikey=$apiKey (DONE IN THIS STEP)
- 4 Using the collection and environment URIs acquired in steps 3 and 4, run the collection as follows:

$ newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/$uid?apikey=$apiKey" \
    --environment "https://api.getpostman.com/environments/$uid?apikey=$apiKey"
    
    
For this request peforming step 3 and noting down environments uid from newmanProduction since that is associated with the collection - Postman Collection we r using
- "uid": "7579022-339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b",
- environment name - "name": "newmanProduction"

Using multiple environments within Newman
- Name used newmanProduction 
- Collection used to subsistute this value is Postman collection

Substitution Postman Collection
- in the postman collection substituting the URL value within an environment variable allows us to passs {{url}}/XXXX for each request
- HOWEVER, when running the CLI you are fucked because newman  doesnt know how to substitue {{url}} (i.e... access environments like postman does)
  - {{url}}/get?isGood=true&isBad=false

Newman command line format as seen in documentation
-newman run <collection-file-source> [options]



SOLUTION 1 - downloading environments from Postman
- https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman#command-line-options and look for solution within command line options you think you could use
- if get stuck go down and solution is posted


solution 1  command line option
- --environment "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/$uid?apikey=$apiKey" --environment "path/to/environments"
  - for environment you need to download the environments from within postman and best is to place in same location as where running command line from (pwd to find)
  - newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/7579022-0e940dbe-cc9d-4a88-9a08-cc89837bde19?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" --environment "newmanProduction.postman_environment.json" 


SOLUTION 2 -- appending specific environment variable
- https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman#command-line-options and look for solution within command line options you think you could use
- if get stuck go down and solution is posted


solution  command line option 
- --env-var 
  - use --env-var "<environment-variable-name>=<environment-variable-value>"
  - "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/$uid?apikey=$apiKey" --env-var "<environment-variable-name>=<environment-variable-value>"
Allows the specification of environment variables via the command line, in a key=value format. Multiple CLI environment variables can be added by using --env-var multiple times, like so: --env-var "foo=bar" --env-var "alpha=beta"
  - newman run  "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/37579022-0e940dbe-cc9d-4a88-9a08-cc89837bde19?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" --env-var "url=https://httpbin.org"
 

SOLUTION 3 --appending ALL environemnt variables within collection
- https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman#command-line-options and look for solution within command line options you think you could use
- if get stuck go down and solution is posted


solution  command line option 
- environment variable uid
- newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/$uid?apikey=$apiKey" --environment "https://api.getpostman.com/environments/$uid?apikey=$apiKey"
Allows the specification of all environment variables via the command line
  - newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/7579022-339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" --environment "https://api.getpostman.com/environments/7579022-0e940dbe-cc9d-4a88-9a08-cc89837bde19?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f"
 
IN JENKINS if you DONT WANT A LONG STRING YOU CAN USE "\" between each command that is run, example below
- example: nemwan run "abc" \(Enter to create new line after the slash from keyboard) --environment "bcd" (this will be on second line)
newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/7579022-339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" \
--environment "https://api.getpostman.com/environments/7579022-0e940dbe-cc9d-4a88-9a08-cc89837bde19?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f"

item.name: Using Newman w/ Postman API - Individual Collections using CLI

request.description:
Continuation of Preview step - Using Newman w/ Postman API - Acccess ALL Collections - PM

Here we will use the Neman CLI to obtain the same specific colleciton as done in above request.
- Command - newman run "URL"
-  Note - need to substitute UID path variable in URL since CLI does not know how to substitute 
   - URL - newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/7579022-339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" 
     - if using using environment vairable {{url}} then we need to append --env-var "url=https://httpbin.org" to the need
       - newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/7579022-339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" --env-var "url=https://httpbin.org"
     - if NOT using environment variable then what we have for URL above is fine

Installing Jenkins on MAC
- Parent Link - https://www.jenkins.io/doc/book/installing/macos/ 
- Downloading and Installing Jenkins specifically via homebrew - https://www.jenkins.io/download/lts/macos/


Steps to Begin
1. Create a new job in jenkins (select new item)
2. Need to check if Newman, Node and NPM are all installed on machine running jenkins, THIS IS A MUST
	- newman --version
	- npm --version
	- node --version
3. Create Job to check, specifically freestyle project option
4. Enter Name of freestyle project
5. Select OK
6. If you dont know go to Configure page select Job and then select Configure option on left navigation pane
7. When configure loads select General Tab-> [Add a Build Config] drop down and select "Execute shell" option
8. Since we want to check step 2 perform the following commands similar to how we did in terminal
   node --verison, newman --version, npm --version
9. Save Configuration
10. Try a build
11. If builds fine (build is not red) you can continue to step XX
12. If build fails you need to install whichever plugins are missing (node, newman, npm) 
   - to install npm - https://plugins.jenkins.io/pipeline-npm/
   - to install nodejs - https://plugins.jenkins.io/nodejs/
   - to install newman - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/53142260/run-newman-in-jenkins
13. Build your project

Expected - all values should be returned successfully


Jenkins Commands
- macOS Installers for Jenkins LTS
- Install the latest LTS version: brew install jenkins-lts.
- Install a specific LTS version: brew install jenkins-lts@YOUR_VERSION.
- Start the Jenkins service: brew services start jenkins-lts.
- Restart the Jenkins service: brew services restart jenkins-lts.
- Update the Jenkins version: brew upgrade jenkins-lts.

If the previous request doesnt work try troubelshooting

Troubleshooting Jenkins Problems (for Windows)

If you are running Jenkins locally, it may happen that you encounter some problems. The most common ones are listed below.

Node and Newman are installed locally but do not work in Jenkins If you are getting a version output for node and newman while opening a terminal but they do not work in Jenkins, it might be related to the fact that Jenkins runs as a different user.

Possible solution #1

In Windows, you need to set node.js folder path into system variables.

1) open Control Panel -> System and Security -> System -> Advanced System Settings -> Environment Variables

2) in "System variables" find variable PATH and add node.js folder path as value. Usually it is C:\Program Files\nodejs;. If the variable doesn't exist, create it.

For newman you also need to add the folder where the newman bin was installed (usually it is something like: C:\Users\YOURUSERNAME\AppData\Roaming\npm

3) Restart your computer.

Possible solution #2

Please also look into the responses on Stackoverflow as well:

https://stackoverflow.com/q/53142260/766177

Possible solution #3

Contributed by William nkosi to solve the error with "node: command not found"

https://www.techcoil.com/blog/how-i-make-my-jenkins-slave-windows-service-recognize-the-global-modules-installed-by-npm/

Encoding Problems (" ") If you see a bunch of " " chars in the Jenkins console output, try one of the following solutions:

Possible solution #1

Try the changes as shown here: https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/how-resolve-utf-8-encoding-issue-jenkins-ajuram-salim/ . After this restart Jenkins and it should work better (contributed by Phil. Many thanks).

Possible solution #2

Have a look at this medium post:

https://medium.com/pacroy/how-to-fix-jenkins-console-log-encoding-issue-on-windows-a1f4b26e0db4 (contributed by Javier Gironella San Juan. Many thanks).

Possible solution #3

Try adding ONE of the following newman options to the newman run command:

--disable-unicode

--color off

Error: java.io.IOException: Cannot run program "sh" This happens if you have specified your Windows command as "Execute shell" rather than "Execute Windows batch command".

Troubleshooting Jenkins Problems (for macOS, Linux)
Newman - command not found
Go to Manage Jenkins.




Select Manage Nodes.


Identify the node you want to configure (typically master) and click on the gear icon.


Create an environment variable called PATH with the value /usr/local/bin:$PATH

item.name: API Collecton - running with Jenkins + Failures + CLI & JUNIT Reports

request.description:
In this section we see what is the best approach for failures when running api from jenkins

Setup
1. Configure one item in collection to fail
2. Rebuild on jenkins

Expected - failure should be reported

PROBLEM
- if you have a lot of assertions and requests when something fails its not easy to check the console and check for the specific one which failed. This is why using REPORTS that Jenkins supports can be very be beneficial

SOLUTION
- we can use Newman and configure which reporters we can utilize  https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman#configuring-reporters
  -  using command -r <reporter-name>, --reporters <reporter-name>
  -  we specify cli and junit for reporters since thes seem to be the best 
  -  append the following --reporters cli,junit to the already current command we are running from the previous requesst

newman run "https://api.getpostman.com/collections/7579022-339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" \
--environment "https://api.getpostman.com/environments/7579022-0e940dbe-cc9d-4a88-9a08-cc89837bde19?apikey=PMAK-5fc15a77ce911f004373dd61-f92f9b1a686b1e4eba6fa1a629b0d4b65f" \
--reporters cli,junit

- now that we have the reporters we want to use we can now specify where we want the file outputted by appending the below
  - https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman#junitxml-reporter
    - --reporter-junit-export <path> OR --reporter-junit-export "newman/reportl.xml" for example which will be saved INSIDE OUR WORKSPACE
      - workspace is within location - http://localhost:8080/job/http_bin_api_tests/ws/newman/
      - if you dont specificy filepath it will get saved into the newman work space by default and have a name like newman-run-report-2021-01-24-20-40-21-088-0.xml

item.name: API Collection - Publishing Report in Jenkins - JUNIT

request.description:
In this lesson we publish reports in Jenkins. 
- when we output the file as in the previous step (cli,json) jensking still has NO IDEA about the report so we need to congire it so it does know about it
- to publish the report perform the below
1. Select Configuration
2. Select Post-build actions --these actions get performed about the build has completed
3. Select "Publish JUnit test result report"
4. You will see several options appear below
5. We are interested in "Test Report XML sections"  --RECALL we created the test report in previous step
6. Within the location type where we created the test report "newman/reportl.xml"
		NOTE - for torubleshooting its always best to Create the report in a location then publish it so you are sure where you placed it when attempting to publish it
7. Select Save
8. Create another build ensuring at least 1 test fails (change 200 to 201 for instance)
9. Wait for build to finish
10. Refresh  Page -- we do this so latest build results are seen as page does not auto refresh
11. Select Last Build
12. On Last Build page you will notice there is a Test Result section now
13. Select the Test Results option
14. Observe you see a detailed result of the failures and passes
15. Per investivation observe when you drill down you see will see the general reason and also the finalized stack trave

Example - 

--All Failed Test
--Test Name 
- PostmanCollection.Status code is 200
--Error Details
	--expected response to have status code 201 but got 200
Stack Trace
	--
		Failed 1 times.
		Collection JSON ID: 339a3cd3-53fe-4216-be2d-4902cbcc0c0b.
        Collection name: Postman collection.
        Request name: GET with URL Params.
        Test description: Status code is 200.
        Error message: expected response to have status code 201 but got 200.
        Stacktrace: AssertionError: expected response to have status code 201 but got 200

Expected - report should be published and failure information should be see

NOTE - eventually after many reports are run you will see an automatically generated trend callled "Test Result Trend" which will show you the last 5-10 builds which have completed and the failures (if any) which have occured within each build

item.name: API Collection - Publishing Report in Jenkins - HTML

request.description:
Thes are the steps to create an HTML Report in Jenkins.

SETUP 
1. Run the two items below locally
     - npm install -g newman-reporter-htmlextra 
     - npm install -g newman-reporter-html
2. From the Global Build configurations (http://localhost:8080/configureTools/) 
2. create two new NodeJS Installations (run them on the CLI server also)
   -Name = node for both and within each Global npm packages to install use one of the below items
     - npm install -g newman-reporter-htmlextra 
     - npm install -g newman-reporter-html
3. Save Changes
4. Install HTML Publisher Plugin https://plugins.jenkins.io/htmlpublisher/
   -select item to Donwload and Install after download
   -wait for jenkins to reboot
5. EXTRAs INFORMATION - 
   - HTML Reporter Overview  - https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman-reporter-html#readme
   - Might Need -- Documentation to Install to use HTML Report - https://github.com/postmanlabs/newman#html-reporter
6. Run scripts in Jenkins (this allows the html report to appear nice, without this the format will be no bueno) -- FIND WAY TO NOT HAVE TO DO THIS
   - Try to run this script in Jenkins Dashboard > Manage Jenkins > Script Console
   - System.setProperty("hudson.model.DirectoryBrowserSupport.CSP", "sandbox allow-scripts;")



Creating Report
1. Go to Project  (http://localhost:8080/job/http_bin_api_tests/) if not already there
2. Select Configure
3. For Execute Shell add htm reporters to the list, --reporters cli,junit,html
3. For Execute Shell option add html to --reproters list and add --reporter-html-export "newman/report.html" as example report name 
3. Add Post Build Option
4. Select Publish HTML Reports
5. For HTML Directory Archive put newman --where report will be published (step 3 without /report.html)
6. Update index pages to report.html --name of report (step 3 without newman/)
7. Save 
8. Build
9. Navigate to Workspaces

Expected - html report should be seen

10. Select HTML Report

Expected - should be formatted nicely

item.name: API Collection - Customizing HTML Reports in Jenkins

Using logging option example - Observe in template downloaded there is a section with "Request Information" --Request Information 17. Below this type "Debug :{{_inspect response}}" - still need to figure this out with example 18.

Troubleshooting HTML reports
My report is generated in Jenkins but it is not properly formatted

item.name: API Collection - Running w/ Github Report via Jenkins

request.description:
The following steps details how to run your postman request from a git repository
1. Log into Git / Create Account
2. Upload the following files
   -environments file for your collection
   -postman api collection file
3.
